name: Apple___Apple_scab
cause: Fungus Venturia inaequalis spreads in cool, moist weather causing dark velvety lesions on leaves and fruit.
cure: Remove fallen leaves, improve air circulation, and spray preventive fungicides (mancozeb or captan) at early season. Neem oil works as organic prevention.

name: Apple___Black_rot
cause: Botryosphaeria obtusa infects through wounds during warm humid periods causing leaf spots and fruit rot.
cure: Prune infected twigs and remove mummified fruits. Apply thiophanate-methyl or copper fungicide during spring.

name: Apple___Cedar_apple_rust
cause: Gymnosporangium fungus spreads between juniper and apple trees forming orange rust spots.
cure: Remove nearby junipers, apply myclobutanil fungicide during bud break, and plant rust-resistant apple varieties.

name: Apple___Bitter_rot
cause: Colletotrichum fungus infects fruit during rainy warm season causing circular sunken lesions.
cure: Remove infected fruit, prune branches for airflow, and apply captan or azoxystrobin fungicide every 2 weeks.

name: Apple___healthy
cause: Tree is disease-free with uniform green foliage and proper photosynthesis.
cure: Maintain sanitation, prune yearly, and fertilize balanced NPK for long-term resistance.

name: Blueberry___Anthracnose
cause: Colletotrichum acutatum causes reddish leaf lesions and soft fruit rot in wet weather.
cure: Prune infected canes and spray chlorothalonil or azoxystrobin at early flowering.

name: Blueberry___healthy
cause: Foliage is lush and disease-free with optimal soil pH (4.5–5.5).
cure: Ensure proper mulching, maintain low soil pH, and promote airflow to prevent fungal infection.

name: Cherry___Powdery_mildew
cause: Podosphaera clandestina forms white powdery growth on leaves in warm humid climate.
cure: Prune dense canopies, avoid wet foliage, and apply sulfur or myclobutanil fungicide in early infection.

name: Cherry___Brown_rot
cause: Monilinia fungus infects fruit and leaves during humid weather forming brown lesions.
cure: Remove infected fruit and spray captan or propiconazole during bloom time.

name: Cherry___healthy
cause: Tree shows no infection; leaves are glossy and firm.
cure: Maintain irrigation scheduling and nutrient level, inspect during rainy seasons.

name: Corn___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_leaf_spot
cause: Cercospora zeae-maydis causes brown-gray rectangular lesions moving up the plant.
cure: Use resistant corn hybrids, rotate crops, and apply fungicides (triazoles or strobilurins) at tasseling stage.

name: Corn___Common_rust
cause: Puccinia sorghi forms rust-colored pustules reducing photosynthesis.
cure: Plant rust-resistant varieties and apply foliar fungicides like azoxystrobin when symptoms appear.

name: Corn___Northern_Leaf_Blight
cause: Exserohilum turcicum causes cigar-shaped gray leaf blight under high humidity.
cure: Use resistant hybrid seeds, practice crop rotation, and spray propiconazole during silking.

name: Corn___Anthracnose_Leaf_Blight
cause: Colletotrichum graminicola causes dark water-soaked lesions expanding on upper leaves.
cure: Till crop residue, plant resistant hybrids, and apply fungicide at V5–V7 stages.

name: Corn___healthy
cause: Leaves are shiny and green with no fungal or pest activity.
cure: Balanced fertilization, pest monitoring, and timely irrigation ensure sustained health.

name: Grape___Black_rot
cause: Guignardia bidwellii causes leaf lesions leading to shriveled black fruit.
cure: Remove diseased fruit, prune infected shoots, and spray mancozeb at early shoot growth.

name: Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles)
cause: Multiple fungi degrade trunk tissue causing tiger-striping leaves and fruit shrivel.
cure: Remove infected canes, protect trunk from injury, and apply fungicidal paste at cuts.

name: Grape___Downy_mildew
cause: Plasmopara viticola forms yellow oil spots and white mildew underside in wet conditions.
cure: Spray copper-based fungicides or metalaxyl, ensure good drainage and canopy airflow.

name: Grape___healthy
cause: Canopy shows balanced growth and no infections.
cure: Maintain vineyard hygiene, trimming and nutrient supplements to prevent mildew and rot.

name: Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening)
cause: Bacterial disease by Candidatus Liberibacter via psyllid insects causing yellow blotchy leaves.
cure: Control psyllids using insecticides, remove infected trees immediately, plant certified disease-free saplings.

name: Orange___Citrus_Canker
cause: Xanthomonas axonopodis causes raised corky leaf spots and fruit blemishing.
cure: Copper fungicide + zinc sprays; destroy severely affected branches and avoid overhead irrigation.

name: Peach___Bacterial_spot
cause: Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni causes dark sunken lesions on leaves and fruits.
cure: Apply copper sprays during bloom and prune infected shoots; grow resistant cultivars.

name: Peach___Leaf_Curl
cause: Taphrina deformans causes distorted thick curled leaves during cool wet weather.
cure: Apply copper or chlorothalonil fungicide before bud swell, remove infected leaves.

name: Peach___healthy
cause: Leaves are firm green with no spots or distortion.
cure: Maintain proper pruning, avoid overhead irrigation, and ensure balanced nutrition.

name: Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot
cause: Xanthomonas bacteria cause brown greasy leaf lesions and fruit spotting.
cure: Avoid wetting foliage, rotate crops yearly, and apply copper bactericides bi-weekly.

name: Pepper,_bell___Mosaic_Virus
cause: Tobacco mosaic virus causes mottled yellow leaves and stunted plant growth.
cure: Remove infected plants, sanitize tools, and apply neem oil to prevent vector insects.

name: Pepper,_bell___healthy
cause: Leaf surface shows no curling, spotting, or yellowing.
cure: Provide full sunlight, maintain moderate fertilizer and humidity monitoring.

name: Potato___Early_blight
cause: Alternaria solani produces brown circular spots with concentric rings on older leaves.
cure: Remove infected leaves and apply protectant fungicides (chlorothalonil or mancozeb) weekly.

name: Potato___Late_blight
cause: Phytophthora infestans causes rapid foliage collapse under rainy conditions.
cure: Apply proactive fungicides (metalaxyl or cymoxanil) and destroy infected plant debris.

name: Potato___Black_Scurf
cause: Rhizoctonia solani forms black crusty lesions on tubers and stunted shoots.
cure: Use certified disease-free seed, treat soil with fungicidal drench before planting.

name: Potato___healthy
cause: Leaves are upright and evenly green without spotting.
cure: Irrigate on schedule and ensure proper soil drainage to avoid tuber disease.

name: Squash___Powdery_mildew
cause: Erysiphe cichoracearum forms white powdery growth in warm dry climates.
cure: Use sulfur sprays early, irrigate at soil level, and maintain plant spacing.

name: Strawberry___Leaf_scorch
cause: Diplocarpon earlianum causes purple spots expanding into dry brown margins.
cure: Remove infected leaves and apply fungicides during flowering (mancozeb or captan).

name: Strawberry___Botrytis_Fruit_Rot
cause: Botrytis cinerea creates gray fuzzy mold on berries in humid weather.
cure: Remove old fruit, improve airflow, and spray fenhexamid during blooming.

name: Strawberry___healthy
cause: Bright green leaves without browning or fungal patches.
cure: Avoid wet foliage, provide mulching, and ensure good sunlight exposure.

name: Tomato___Bacterial_spot
cause: Xanthomonas spp. cause water-soaked dark lesions enlarging over time.
cure: Use copper bactericides, rotate crops, and avoid leaf wetting during irrigation.

name: Tomato___Early_blight
cause: Alternaria solani causes dark concentric leaf spots and yellow withering.
cure: Remove early lesions and spray chlorothalonil or copper fungicide bi-weekly.

name: Tomato___Late_blight
cause: Phytophthora infestans forms large black water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems.
cure: Destroy infected plants immediately and apply systemic fungicides like mefenoxam.

name: Tomato___Fusarium_Wilt
cause: Fusarium oxysporum blocks water movement causing yellowing and wilting from bottom leaves.
cure: Remove infected plants, treat soil with Trichoderma bio-fungus, and use resistant F-varieties.

name: Tomato___Leaf_Mold
cause: Passalora fulva causes yellow patches turning brown in high humidity.
cure: Improve ventilation, water early in the day, and spray mancozeb or copper fungicide.

name: Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot
cause: Septoria lycopersici produces tiny brown round spots with light centers.
cure: Remove infected foliage and apply protective fungicides during fruit setting.

name: Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider_mite
cause: Tetranychus urticae mites feed on leaves causing yellow speckling and silk webbing.
cure: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap and increase humidity to reduce mite activity.

name: Tomato___Target_Spot
cause: Corynespora cassiicola forms dark circular sunken lesions with yellow halos.
cure: Reduce humidity and apply chlorothalonil-based fungicides every 10 days.

name: Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus
cause: Whitefly-transmitted virus causing curled yellow leaves and stunting.
cure: Use sticky traps, apply insecticidal soap for whitefly control, and remove infected plants early.

name: Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus
cause: Mechanical viral transmission creates mosaic mottling and leaf deformation.
cure: Sanitize tools with bleach, avoid handling tobacco, and remove infected plants.

name: Tomato___healthy
cause: Plant is disease-free showing firm green foliage and healthy photosynthesis.
cure: Maintain spacing, balanced fertilization, and regular monitoring to prevent disease.
